title: China Aims Its Propaganda Firehose at the BBC
description: The alleged digital operation has deployed hundreds of websites and social media accounts to attack the broadcaster's reporting.

title: The T-Mobile Breach Is Much Worse Than It Had to Be
description: The vast majority of victims weren’t even T-Mobile customers. Now their information is for sale on the dark web.

title: Millions of Web Camera and Baby Monitor Feeds Are Exposed
description: A vulnerability in the Kalay platform leaves countless IoT devices susceptible to hackers.

title: The T-Mobile Data Breach Is One You Can’t Ignore
description: Hackers claim to have obtained the data of 100 million people—including sensitive personal information.

title: How to Send Messages That Automatically Disappear
description: Need to be discreet? Here's how to set up vanishing texts, photos, or videos in most popular chat apps.

title: Security News This Week: A Hacker Stole $610M of Cryptocurrency—and Returned Most of It
description: Plus: An Apple lawsuit, a VPN audit, and more of the week's top security news.

title: How the Far Right Exploded on Steam and Discord
description: New research found that several of the major gaming platforms are hosting extremist activity, from racist livestreams to open support for neo-Nazis.

title: A Simple Software Fix Could Limit Location Data Sharing
description: Carriers know where you are every time your phone reconnects to the cell network—but with Pretty Good Phone Privacy, they wouldn’t have to.

title: A 5G Shortcut Leaves Phones Exposed to Stingray Surveillance
description: You may not have the full story about what network you're on—and how well you're protected.

title: The NYPD Had a Secret Fund for Surveillance Tools
description: Documents reveal that police bought facial-recognition software, vans equipped with x-ray machines, and “stingray” cell site simulators—with no public oversight.

title: What You Should Know About the Google Play Store Changes
description: With the first updates kicking in this month, Android apps should be more streamlined and lightweight. Google is also getting a greater level of control.

title: Security News This Week: Microsoft Edge’s ‘Super Duper Secure Mode’ Does What It Says
description: Plus: Facebook account hacks, Instagram-ban scammers, and more of the week’s top security news.

title: AI Wrote Better Phishing Emails Than Humans in a Recent Test
description: Researchers found that tools like OpenAI's GPT-3 helped craft devilishly effective spearphishing messages.

title: All the Ways Spotify Tracks You—and How to Stop It
description: Whether you're listening to workout music or a "cooking dinner" playlist, the app can show you ads based on your mood and what you're doing right now.

title: Messaging Apps Have an Eavesdropping Problem
description: Vulnerabilities in Signal, Facebook Messenger, Google Duo, and more all point to a pervasive privacy issue.

title: Apple Walks a Privacy Tightrope to Spot Child Abuse in iCloud
description: With a new capability to search for illegal material not just in the cloud but on user devices, the company may have opened up a new front in the encryption wars.

title: Watch a Hacker Hijack a Capsule Hotel’s Lights, Fans, and Beds
description: It’s not a ghost. It’s a half-dozen vulnerabilities in a digital automation system.

title: Citizen's New Service Helps Paying Users Summon the Cops
description: The crime-tracking app is charging $20 per month to give subscribers access to their own virtual security service.

title: France Cracked Down on Google’s Ad Tech. What’s Next?
description: The French Competition Agency has hit the company with $855 million in fines this year. The money is meaningless—but the changes could be profound.

title: Hospitals Still Use Pneumatic Tubes—and They Can Be Hacked
description: The tech may seem antiquated, but it poses very modern cybersecurity problems.

title: A Guide to RCS, and Why It Makes Texting So Much Better
description: Google is pushing the new standard for Android devices, which promises better security and cooler features than plain old SMS.

title: Security News This Week: The Top 30 Vulnerabilities Include Plenty of Usual Suspects
description: Plus: A sneaky iOS app, a wiper attack in Iran, and more of the week’s top security news.

title: The Privacy Battle That Apple Isn’t Fighting
description: California has begun enforcing a browser-level privacy setting, but you still can’t find that option in Safari or iOS.

title: Phantom Warships Are Courting Chaos in Conflict Zones
description: The latest weapons in the global information war are fake vessels behaving badly.

title: A Controversial Tool Calls Out Thousands of Hackable Websites
description: PunkSpider is back, and crawling hundreds of millions of sites for vulnerabilities.

title: The Shapeshifting Cam Girl Rewriting the Rules of Digital Porn
description: Face-morphing adult content creator Coconut Kitty is ushering in the unsettling future of the medium, one where nothing is as it seems.

title: Security News This Week: Porn Showed Up on Legit News Sites Thanks to Internet Rot
description: Plus: China's pipeline probing, a Chromebook debacle, and more of the week's top security news.

title: The Kaseya Ransomware Nightmare Is Almost Over
description: A decryption tool has emerged, meaning any victims whose systems remain locked up can soon breathe easy.

title: An Explosive Spyware Report Shows the Limits of iOS Security
description: Amnesty International sheds alarming light on an NSO Group surveillance tool—and the gaps in Apple’s and Google's defenses.

title: Venmo Gets More Private—but It's Still Not Fully Safe
description: Eliminating the global feed is a good step. But until the platform offers privacy by default, it remains a liability for many of its users.
